content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The source code is incredibly vibrant and I like the concept

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It's very nice to see some optim contributions, and this one is remarkable in quality. Good work :)
fun scenario
great job
fun puzzle
Great job !!!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Firefighter problems were fixed, and is a very fun and original puzzle. Good job.
This was a really fun puzzle. Thanks for the instruction / test cases.

To reply to an old affirmation you made: the firefighter problem (which is a particular case of your problem, with all 1 in your variables or something like that) is NP-complete on bipartite graphs (and grids happen to be bipartite).

I noted a few typos in statement_fr. Here they are:
Missing space before colon "cellules:"
"paramêtre" should be "paramètre" *2
"autant de valeurS" *2
"elles ne sont ni brûléeS ni sécurisées"
"tu ne pas pas" should be "tu ne peux pas"
"les cellules déjà sécuriséeS"
Also, you didn't translate "The Goal" and "Rules".

I'm not sure about the fact that each cell has three parameters. As you say right after, all trees have the same parameters, and same for houses (and the code is written accordingly). I think it would be clearer with something like "each TYPE of cell (tree or house) has 3 params".

And finally, I think the last part (rules) is a bit dense. Maybe you can split it in paragraphs; something like https://www.codingame.com/training/medium/can-you-save-the-forest---episode-1 (which someone already mentioned).

I hope I didn't discourage you by saying all this; but I think these are minor improvements regarding what you already did, so you should be good! I'd like to see this puzzle to be published, and in particular to see the best scores of the community!
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!
great exercise
Great job!
Very interesting, thanks for the lesson !
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!
you should make it a failure if the person cant pass(get half the full points)else,it isdifficult for one to see if he mad the code to do the job or not.
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!
I just tested this out. Did you code all of this?

Game updated! According to the comments of @Konstant and @eulerscheZahl, I changed the following points:
- Removed the maxLostValue from the input. Each test will be a success
- Balanced each test by making their total value around 10000
- Added a big "random" test. I hope nobody will be able to get an optimal score on this one :p

Oh, that looks interesting, reminds me a bit of https://www.codingame.com/training/medium/can-you-save-the-forest---episode-1
My main concern about an optim game (I haven't written any code to check): how hard is to to achieve a perfect score? There's no point in making it an optim, if the top of the leaderboard is a plateau.

Is max_lost_value necessary as condition? What if game always last to the end. Even when whole forest is burnt.

In test 03 Each cell matters, probably too low  max_lost_value, set to 3 but is this possible to lose less than 5 here?

fire_start_x, fire_start_y are not necessary. It's all in fire_progress. And what if you want to add test with couple of starting fires.

Game looks promissing, good job so far.

Thank you for your feedback ! You are right, I forgot to take into account the 2 cells lost by cutting. I will fix that soon.
About the starting fire, the fact that I ensure there is only one starting position is a choice I made in order to make the problem easier. I think it will enable us to find some strategies that would not work with several starting points (It is the case of the strategy I found). And we need these strategies in order to find a solution efficient enough, since it is an optimization game.
Also, by giving the starting position, it enables us to search the solution before getting the first turn input. It is the fire_progress that I consider as not necessary since it can be simulated, but I gave it for testing and debugging.

Yes, I did, by using some existing templates for the code and some graphical assets provided by CodinGame.
Did you really manage to test it ? Because for me, the button "Test in IDE" is currently broken, without effect, and I am not the only one :'( . It would be interesting to know if this issue doesn't apply to everyone.

In the first version, I put a "maxLostValue" which determines whether or not a test is a success. But as you can see with the comments below, I removed it.
The main reason is that since it is an optimization game, it can be useful to compare some people who "did the job" for the same amount of tests, by comparing how bad are their remaining tests.
Another reason is that CodinGame expects us to stop the execution of a test when it is known to be a failure. In that case a player cannot see "how bad a test is" when not doing the job.
Finally, the job to do for a test is quite hinted by the name of a test, or a player can easily guess it. Some test doesn't even have a target, as the "homogeneous" and "random" tests.

Thanks for your detailed review, as well as for pointing out the fact that this problem is more popular than I thought ! I will try to publish it as ready during the upcoming weekend. Before that I need to correct/improve what you said, create validators and comment some of my code. As you said, it's nothing compared to the whole project :p
Hi ! Thank you for your approval, but I am confused. What do you mean "firefighter problems were fixed" ?
Referring to Cubix's previous statement.
Oh ok, thx, I thought you meant that you found the "firefighter problem" was "resolved", that is the optimal solution could be found with polynomial complexity.
If you use the "test in IDE" at the bottom of the page, you should be able to do it. (Glad to know I'm not alone :) )
Oops, indeed, I forgot this button. Thank you ! I thought I cannot test any puzzle for two days... and that nobody will be able to test my puzzle on its last hours on the top of the contrib page ^^

I updated the project to fix max_lost_value on "Each cell matters".
Also, it seems I missed your first point "Is max_lost_value necessary as condition?". I'm not sure I understand your question, you would like me to remove the win condition, so that each test is a success and the ranking is only computed from the total lost value ?
Yup.

Well, why not. The one little problem I see in this case is "balancing" the tests. If someone doesn't block efficiently the fire on the test 03 with only 13 tree cells, he will lost only a few value, compared to another test with much more value. In other words, someone who fails the test 03 will be less penalized than someone who fails another test. Then I have to increase the base value of the tree cells in the test 03, and even balance the other tests. I will try to do that in the next days.
